item.text: Is the child:
Keep calm. Call for help. Has the child stopped breathing due to choking?
Neck trauma?

Clear the airways. Move the head backwards as shown. Inspect the mouth and remove any foreign body present. Clear the secretions from the throat. Check the airways: look for chest movements, listen for breathing sounds, feel for breath.

Immobilize the neck. Inspect the mouth and remove any foreign body present. Clear the secretions from the throat. Check the airways: look for chest movements, listen for breathing sounds, feel for breath. Use jaw thrust without head tilt. Place the 4th and 5th finger behind the angle of the jaw and move it upwards so that the bottom of the jaw is thrust forwards at 90 degrees to the body.
How old is the child?

Back slaps. Place the child with the head facing down across your arm or thigh. Give 5 blows in the middle of the back with the heel of the hand. If obstruction persists: chest thrusts. Turn the infant over. Give 5 chest thrusts with 2 fingers on the lower half of the sternum. If the obstruction persists: check the infant's mouth for any obstruction that can be removed. If necessary, repeat sequence with back slaps.

Back blows. With the child sitting, kneeling, or lying down: give 5 blows on the child's back with the heel of the hand. If the obstruction persists: Heimlich manoeuvre for an older child who is choking. Get behind the child. Put your arm around his/her body. Make a closed fist just below the sternum. Put the other hand on top and push upwards. Repeat this manoeuvre 5 times. If the obstruction persists: check the child's mouth for any obstruction that can be removed. If necessary, repeat sequence with back blows.
Keep calm. Call for help, keep the child on its side in the recovery position. Prepare glucose and diazepam. Administer oxygen. Continue with convulsion management.

Keep calm. Call for help. 

Keep the child on its side in the recovery position (unless there is severe trauma: immobilize) 

Administer oxygen (if available) to maintain saturation > 90%. 

Prepare glucose and prepare for the transfer after treatment.  

VERY SEVERE DISEASE: this child requires URGENT REFERRAL TO HOSPITAL. Give pre-referral treatment.

extension.valueMarkdown:
*   Poor muscle tone 
*   Does not interact with the environment 
*   Weak cry or inconsolable 
*   Neck stiffness 
*   Cyanosis 
*   Severe jaundice 
*   Severe conjunctival or palmar pallor
*   Grunting 
*   Unable to drink/breastfeed 
*   Vomits everything

item.text: CHECK FOR GENERAL DANGER SIGNS. Are at least one of the following danger signs present:
VERY SEVERE DISEASE: the child requires URGENT REFERRAL TO HOSPITAL. Give pre-referral treatment.
History of convulsion(s) during current illness?
Complete the assessment of the convulsion(s)
Tender swelling behind the ear?
Mastoiditis. Pre-referral treatment: Ceftriaxone IM 100mg/kg and Paracetamol for the pain. URGENT REFERRAL TO HOSPITAL.
Pus draining from the ear?
Any ear pain?
Is the child < 2 year?
Temperature less more than or equal to 39 degrees celsius or pain for more than 2 days?
Unclassified ear problem
For how long?
